author: ripostex
content: I'm confused by geth's gas limit calculations. It looks like they're reusing w.config.GasCeil (which is presumably set to ~ 15M today) as a target gas limit post 1559. If this value isn't modified we'll end up with half size blocks. Are miners supposed to flip this value to 30M after the fork?

author: justinleroux
content:
Hope it's OK to ask implementation questions here!

I was asked to relay the following inquiries from our team:

> Can you double check that `maxFeePerGas` must be >= `maxPriorityFeePerGas`?
> 
> And is a reasonable way to display this to consider `maxPriorityFeePerGas` as the minimum and the `maxFeePerGas` as the maximum gas a user will pay (so we would display e.g. `10 - 20 GWei`)

author: timbeiko
content:
> Can you double check that maxFeePerGas must be >= maxPriorityFeePerGas?
Yes

author: timbeiko
content:
This is part of the EIP, <@!349723964659990528>: 

`assert transaction.max_fee_per_gas >= transaction.max_priority_fee_per_gas`

author: timbeiko
content:
> And is a reasonable way to display this to consider maxPriorityFeePerGas as the minimum and the maxFeePerGas as the maximum gas a user will pay (so we would display e.g. 10 - 20 GWei)

The minimum is probably better as the current base fee + `maxPriorityFeePerGas`

author: jgm
content: Regarding the UX for users with EIP-1559: is the idea to try to come to some sort of agreement on a general method of allowing users to see current base fee and some sort of tip metric for blocks in an attempt to ascertain the values they should provide when broadcasting a transaction, or is it up to each wallet provider to come up with their own systems and methods?

author: perama
content:
The door is opened for new ways to communicate "transaction cost" to the user. Each wallet has to opportunity to take it in a direction that they want 

For the early post-fork period I expect to see different approaches appear. New formats that work well might then be adopted by other wallets. 

One general idea is: it's likely that the average user won't need to see much, just show them a cost and hide the rest 

Another idea is: the behind-the-scenes formula for the fee is likely programmable. I expect that there will be some good formulas emerge, but the user might not see these. The feeHistory API is probably going to underpin these.

author: perama
content:
E.g. use the API to find the floor for the priority fee that the block producers are accepting in recent blocks, then use some multiple of the base fee to generate a max fee. Then multiply by the gas limit and show that user the cost in ether and ask if they are happy. 

It might be enough to do that, but we wait and see. Perhaps the basefee rises more frequently and for longer than we expect and that multiple needs to be predicted better from the amount of recent 100% used blocks.
